item.title: Characterization of the sigma-field associated with a stopping time
item.description:
In Section 35 of Probability and Measure, after defining the $\sigma$-field $\mathscr{F}_\tau$ associated with a stopping time $\tau$, Billingsley wrote:

If $\tau(\omega) < \infty$ for all $\omega$ and $\mathscr{F}n = \sigma(X_1, \ldots, X_n)$, then $I_A(\omega) = I_A(\omega’)$ for all $A$ in $\mathscr{F}$ if and only if $X_i(\omega_1) = X_i(\omega_2)$ for $i \leq \tau(\omega_1) = \tau(\omega_2)$: The information in $\mathscr{F}$ consists of values $\tau(\omega), X_1(\omega), \ldots, X{\tau(\omega)}(\omega)$.

How to verify this statement?
